title: Texas Geography - Location, Terrain & Climate
content:
Texas is located in the southern United States, bordering Mexico to the south, and is the second-largest state in the country by both area and population.

[FACTBOX]
Land Area: 695,622 km², about the size of Germany
Highest Point: Guadalupe Peak, 2,667 meters
Lowest Point: Gulf of Mexico, sea level
Coastline: 624 km
Borders: Mexico, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana
Climate Type: temperate, with arid and humid subtropical regions
[/FACTBOX]

[SECTION] Location & Borders [/SECTION]
Texas is situated in the south-central part of the United States, with the **Rio Grande** forming its border with Mexico to the south. The state is bounded by the US states of New Mexico to the west, Oklahoma to the north, Arkansas to the northeast, and Louisiana to the east. To the southeast, Texas has a coastline along the **Gulf of Mexico**, which provides access to the Atlantic Ocean and international trade routes. The state's strategic location has made it an important hub for trade and commerce, with several major **ports** and **border crossings**.

The geography of Texas is diverse, with a range of landscapes and climates that support a wide variety of flora and fauna. The state's location in the southern United States means that it experiences a generally warm climate, with **cold winters** in the north and **hot summers** throughout the state. The **Gulf Coast** region is prone to **hurricanes** and **tropical storms**, which can bring heavy rainfall and strong winds to the area. Despite these risks, Texas is a popular destination for tourists and businesses alike, with its rich history, vibrant culture, and stunning natural beauty.

[SECTION] Terrain & Landscape [/SECTION]
The terrain of Texas is varied, with a range of **mountains**, **rivers**, **deserts**, and **coastlines** that support a diverse range of ecosystems. The **Guadalupe Mountains** in western Texas are a popular destination for **hiking** and **camping**, with their rugged peaks and scenic vistas. The **Rio Grande** forms the border with Mexico, and its valley is an important agricultural region, with **irrigation** supporting the growth of crops such as **cotton** and **citrus fruits**. The **Panhandle** region in northern Texas is home to the **Great Plains**, a vast grassland that stretches across the central United States.

The **Gulf Coast** region is characterized by a flat, low-lying **coastal plain**, with **beaches**, **bays**, and **estuaries** that support a wide range of marine life. The **Piney Woods** region in eastern Texas is a dense forest of **pine** and **hardwood** trees, with a diverse range of wildlife, including **deer**, **turkeys**, and **alligators**. The **Hill Country** region in central Texas is a scenic area of rolling hills and **wildflowers**, with a strong focus on **viticulture** and **wine production**.

[SECTION] Climate By Season [/SECTION]
[TABLE]
| Season | Months | Temperature Range | Rainfall | Conditions |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Spring | March to May | 15-25°C | 70-100 mm | mild, wildflowers in bloom |
| Summer | June to August | 25-35°C | 50-80 mm | hot, humid, thunderstorms |
| Autumn | September to November | 10-20°C | 50-100 mm | mild, comfortable, foliage |
| Winter | December to February | 0-10°C | 30-60 mm | cool, dry, occasional cold fronts |
[/TABLE]

[SECTION] Best Time To Visit [/SECTION]
[CALLOUT] Best months: March to May and September to November. Why: these periods offer mild temperatures and comfortable conditions, with a range of outdoor activities and festivals to enjoy. Avoid: June to August, as the summer heat and humidity can be oppressive, and December to February, when cold fronts can bring chilly weather and occasional rain. [/CALLOUT]

[SECTION] Natural Highlights [/SECTION]
- **Big Bend National Park** is a stunning natural area in southwestern Texas, with rugged mountains, scenic rivers, and diverse wildlife.
- **Guadalupe Mountains National Park** is a popular destination for hiking and camping, with its scenic vistas and unique geology.
- **Padre Island National Seashore** is a protected area of coastline, with **beaches**, **dunes**, and **wildlife** habitats to explore.
- **Rio Grande River** forms the border with Mexico, and its valley is an important agricultural region, with **irrigation** supporting the growth of crops.
- **Caddo Lake** is a unique and diverse ecosystem, with **cypress swamps**, **bayous**, and **wildlife** habitats to explore.
- **Palo Duro Canyon** is a scenic area of rugged hills and valleys, with **hiking** and **camping** opportunities, and stunning views of the surrounding landscape.
